bestBHT.bht: A Gentile woman, responding to Jesus, acknowledges her position and declares that even the dogs under the table are allowed to eat the crumbs from the children's table. She believes that just a crumb of power and grace from Jesus can cast the devil out of her daughter. Instead of taking offense at being called a dog, she cleverly uses the situation to plead for her child, recognizing that even the Gentiles are entitled to a small favor or benefit.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Yes, Lord—or, as the same word is rendered in :-. 'Truth, Lord.'"
That's my whole case. Not of the children? True. A dog? True also: Yet the dogs under the table are allowed to eat of the children's crumbs—the droppings from their master's full table."
One crumb of power and grace from Thy table shall cast the devil out of my daughter.
Marvin Vincent: The children 's crumbs. See on Matthew 14:26. This would indicate that the little dogs were pet dogs of the children, their masters.
Laid [βεβλημενον] . Lit., thrown. She had probably experienced some fearful convulsion when the demon departed.
Archibald T. Robertson: Even the dogs under the table...eat of the children's crumbs."
Little dogs, little scraps of bread, little children.
Instead of resenting Christ's words about giving the children's bread to the dogs (Gentiles) in verse Mark 7:27, she instantly turned it to the advantage of her plea for her little daughter.
John Gill: yet the dogs under the table eat of the children's crumbs"
signifying that she did not envy the blessings of the Jews
such unworthy Gentiles as she, might be allowed a small benefit or favour by the bye

bhtAttempts.bht: In Mark 7:28, a Gentile woman responds to Jesus after He refers to her as a dog. With humility and sincerity, she acknowledges her position and states that even the dogs under the table are permitted to eat the crumbs from the children's table. She affirms her belief that even a fragment of power and grace from Jesus will be enough to deliver her daughter from the demon. Despite being called a dog, she turns the situation to her advantage, recognizing that even the Gentiles are entitled to some benefit or favor from Jesus.

A Gentile woman, responding to Jesus, acknowledges her position and declares that even the dogs under the table are allowed to eat the crumbs from the children's table. She believes that just a crumb of power and grace from Jesus can cast the devil out of her daughter. Instead of taking offense at being called a dog, she cleverly uses the situation to plead for her child, recognizing that even the Gentiles are entitled to a small favor or benefit.

In response to Jesus, a Gentile woman humbly acknowledges her place and states that even the dogs under the table are allowed to eat the children's crumbs. She firmly believes that the tiniest fragment of power and grace from Jesus can deliver her daughter from the demon. Despite being called a dog, she skillfully turns the situation to her advantage, recognizing that even the Gentiles deserve some favor or benefit from Jesus.

In Mark 7:28, a Gentile woman responds to Jesus after He refers to her as a dog. With humility and sincerity, she acknowledges her position and states that even the dogs under the table are permitted to eat the crumbs from the children's table. She affirms her belief that even a fragment of power and grace from Jesus will be enough to deliver her daughter from the demon. Despite being called a dog, she turns the situation to her advantage, recognizing that even the Gentiles are entitled to some benefit or favor from Jesus.

Acknowledging her position, a Gentile woman responds to Jesus being called a dog. She humbly states that even the dogs under the table are permitted to eat the crumbs from the children's table. Believing that even the smallest crumb of power and grace can deliver her daughter from a demon, she skillfully turns the situation to her advantage. She recognizes that even the Gentiles should be entitled to some benefit or favor from Jesus.
